The project will assist 10 member States to take targeted actions to eliminate the worst forms of child labour. This will be achieved by providing critically needed and technical guidance support in the areas of legislation, enforcement, monitoring, development and implementation of national action plans, and improved implementation of policies and social programs with an impact on child labour. This proposal is organized under four components that are mutually reinforcing. The first component will improve specific aspects of national legislation on child labour including its worst forms so that the national legislative framework is in compliance with international standards. The second component will improve monitoring and enforcement of laws and policies related to child labour through improving the capacity of national inspection systems as well as establishing/improving child labour monitoring systems. The third component will build national capacity to develop, validate, adopt and implement their National Action Plans on the elimination of child labour. The forth component aims to enhance implementation of national and local policies and programs and to improve social policies and programs that will have a positive impact on child labour (such as basic education policies and programs, vocational training, social protection services, and employment creation and poverty reduction initiatives). The Project will be implemented by the ILO through its International Program on the Elimination of Child Labour (IPEC), assisted by other relevant ILO units, offices and specialists.

In  November 2022, the Ghana Trades Union Congress (TUC) developed a tool for undertaking a comprehensive analysis of existing collective bargaining agreement (CBA) clauses from nine sectors (two CBAs from the Maritime and Dockworkers Union (MDU), two from the Timber and Woodworkers’ Union (TWU), two from General Agricultural Workers’ Union (GAWU), two from Union of Industry, Commerce and Finance (UNICOF), and one from the Public Services Workers’ Union) to assess the extent to which CBA clauses are still relevant tools for providing tailored needs driven services to existing, new and potential membership. 

Obsolete clauses were updated and revitalised with new clauses addressing new issues in the world of work, including ending violence and harassment, and enhancing safety and health.  From July 2023, the updated CBAs were utilised as tools for organising and attracting new groups of workers resulting in increased unionisation of over 1000 young workers in non standard forms of employment  such as domestic work, gig work, informal economy, temporary and contract based work where the majority of non-unionised groups are located. Ghana TUC has increased membership by 12% and enhanced services packages for improved working conditions and services for young women to report and receive counselling and support on issues related to violence and harassment. The ILO Country policy responses presented within the four pillars of action defined by the ILO to lessen the impact of COVID-19 on businesses, jobs and the most vulnerable members of society provided a useful framework and guidance during the CBA analysis in defining new clauses for integration into existing Collective Bargaining Agreements. During the months of February to May 2023, ILO supported several workshops for fifty trade union industrial relations officers, social partner negotiators and researchers to deepen knowledge and understanding on social dialogue and collective bargaining based on the lessons learnt from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Access to skills recognition has been improved through the development of blended Recognition of Prior Learning using blended RPL assessment packages and an online RPL Platform. NCTP has developed and upgraded eRPL for skills assessment and certification in the hospitality sector. DGVET has recently launched the eRPL platform and assessment for several sectors starting construction and manufacturing sectors. Blended Recognition of Prior Learning has been introduced by the ILO to major TVET stakeholders. In addition, ILO provided a series of funding support to NCTP to develop and upgrade the blended assessment packages and platform. For DGTVET, the ILO provided a first introductory training on eRPL and technical inputs and backstopping for the development online RPL platform. The TVET schools funded the ILO, blended assessment packages have been developed and expanded and used in eRPL platform.

1)El gobierno de la Argentina publicó en marzo de 2022 en el Boletín Oficial el Decreto 144/2022, que reglamentó el artículo 179 de la Ley Nº 20.744 de Contrato de Trabajo. Dicha reglamentación apunta a garantizar el cuidado de los hijos e hijas de las personas trabajadoras. En particular, el Decreto dispone que los establecimientos con más de 100 personas empleadas deberán ofrecer espacios de cuidado para niños y niñas de 45 días a 3 años de edad inclusive a cargo de las personas trabajadoras durante sus jornadas de trabajo. 
2) En junio de 2022, la Dirección de Empleo y Trabajo Decente del Gobierno de la Ciudad de Santa Fe creó y habilitó el Registro único de trabajadoras y trabajadores del cuidado. El registro pone a disposición de quienes requieren servicios de cuidados una base pública de datos y contactos de personas capacitadas para prestarlos. La herramienta es un instrumento de fomento a la profesionalización del trabajo en el sector dado que la inscripción sólo puede realizarse cumplimentando el mínimo de capacitación y formación exigida. Además, facilita el acceso de potenciales empleadores a información sobre aspectos reglamentarios vigentes. También en 2022, la Dirección implementó una medida que apoya el funcionamiento del Registro, compuesta por cursos de capacitación laboral destinados al sector. La medida de política pública “Propuestas de Formación Profesional y Capacitación Laboral en el Sector de los Cuidados” nació en la Mesa Santafesina para el Empleo, que es un espacio de diálogo social y coordinación de políticas destinado a abordar de forma articulada las problemáticas y oportunidades de inserción laboral entre los tres niveles del estado (Nacional, Provincial y Municipal). La mesa se reúne mensualmente y se organiza en ejes temáticos vinculados. 1) Durante 2022 y 2023, en el marco del Programa Conjunto ONU Mujeres-OIT, la OIT contribuyó al fortalecimiento del diálogo tripartito en materia de economía del cuidado con participación de distintas carteras ministeriales y niveles de gobierno en el ámbito de las discusiones en torno al Proyecto de Ley “Cuidar en Igualdad”. Los debates en torno a dicho proyecto promovieron la visibilización de esta temática en la agenda pública y propiciaron – luego de 50 años -la reglamentación del artículo 179 de la Ley Nº 20.744 de Contrato de Trabajo mediante el Decreto 144/2022. De acuerdo al mismo, el cómputo de la cantidad de 100 personas empleadas no distingue entre géneros y se realiza teniendo en cuenta a todas las personas que dependen de la empresa, como así también quienes prestan servicios en el establecimiento principal.
2) Durante el año 2022, la OIT transfirió materiales de formación a la Dirección de Empleo y Trabajo Decente del Gobierno de la Ciudad de Santa Fe, que facilitaron la implementación de cursos de Formación Profesional y Capacitación Laboral en el Sector de los Cuidados. Asimismo, en esa misma línea, la Oficina prestó asistencia técnica a la Dirección de Empleo y Trabajo Decente del Gobierno de la Ciudad de Santa Fe para elaborar una propuesta metodológica de evaluación de diseño e implementación de los cursos previamente citados, con énfasis en la identificación y mitigación de dificultades presentes en su funcionamiento. La Oficina además brindó recomendaciones con el objeto de fomentar la mejora de la calidad de dicha capacitación de la Municipalidad.

1) In 2023, the Ethiopian Embassy in Saudi Arabia and the Ethiopian Consulate General in Lebanon provided improved consular and protection services to 82,573 Ethiopian migrant workers (75% women). Both missions were able to assist in financial claims equivalent to USD282,351 to 228 Ethiopian migrant workers.

2) In 2023, the Mulu Tesfa Domestic Workers Association established 12 new local associations of domestic workers with 114 women members, to better promote the rights of domestic workers in Ethiopia and overseas. It enrolled 1,543 women domestic workers including returning migrants. The Association built the capacity of 7 local level associations to protect rights of domestic workers and established a help desk for grievance resolution.

3) More than 5,000 people improved their livelihoods:

- 1,213 beneficiaries increased their income through self or wage employment, including in green business. 

- 3,187 (2,742 female) potential and returned migrants increased entrepreneurship and core skills, as well as financial education;

- 632 (329 female) beneficiaries accessed a revolving loanable fund of USD 1 million to establish a business.

4) The Ethiopian Employers Federation offered on the job training and linked beneficiaries with employers with substantial production activities in Ethiopia. In 2023, 1,050 employment opportunities were created for potential and return migrants and 2,400 beneficiaries were engaged in sustainable livelihood through self and wage employment.

5) Eight technical and vocational training providers were strengthened through workshop equipment with up-to-date materials and machinery for quality, practical and friendly learning environment. In 2023, 5,254 (56 men) potential and return migrants were capacitated in hotel and tourism, hairdressing, domestic work, and bakery sector by the support of Technical and vocational training centres. 1) With support of the Swiss Government, the ILO provided support to mobilize temporary staff in the missions (Case Support Officers, Liaison Officers, Paralegal Officers and Data Management Officers). The missions were then able to provide better consular protection and services to Ethiopian migrant workers, including registration, and to embed these services in the budgets of the missions.

2) With support of the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, the ILO provided technical assistance to the Mulu Tesfa Domestic Worker Association.

3) With support of the United Kingdom Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation and Multi-Partner Trust Fund, the ILO provided holistic economic and social support to potential and returned migrants.

4) With support of the United Kingdom Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office, the ILO partnered with the Ethiopian Employers Federation and local non-government organizations to provide economic and social empowerment support to more than 4,800 potential and returned migrants.

5) With support of the United Kingdom Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office, the ILO assessed the capacity of TVET providers, focusing on training provision to potential and returned migrants, and provided good and services to 8 centres. Moreover, the ILO enhanced the capacity of 43 technical and vocational training Deans (5 women) on core skills.

8 States in Nigeria (Oyo, Ogun, Lagos, Ondo, Osun, Niger, and Kwara States) adapted the National Action Plan on the elimination of child labour to the context of child labour in the ASGM, COCOA and other sectors specific to these states. These State Action Plans on the elimination child labour in its worst forms were validated over the period February 2022 – June 2023.

The National Orientation Agency has reviewed its five-year strategic plan (2021-2026) to include actions towards the elimination of child labour in Nigeria. The document was reviewed to ensure the mainstreaming of child labour issues into the agency's programmes to enable the agency to provide technical support through advocacy and Social and Behavioural Communication and Change. The reviewed strategic plan was validated in February 2023.

The Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development inaugurated and trained Agricultural Child Labour Desk Officers from the 36 states in Nigeria as well as the FCT in February 2023. These Child Labour Desk Officers are tasked with the responsibility of protecting children from exploitation, hazards, and risks in the agricultural sector in Nigeria. The ILO, with the support of the Government of the Netherlands, supported the states in the adaptation and review of the draft State Action Plans with the various states. The ILO also with the support of the Government of the Netherlands, convened a validation meeting of the State Steering Committee on the Elimination of Child Labour to validate these State Action Plans on the elimination of child labour of 8 States in Nigeria (Oyo, Ogun, Lagos, Ondo, Osun, Niger, and Kwara States).

With the support of the Government of the Netherlands Government, ILO supported the establishment and training of the Community Child Labour Monitoring Committee in Ibala, Osun State in August 2023. The trained Committee members will monitor and report on Child Labour cases in the community and Support the State Steering Committees as well as other stakeholders in their interventions to eliminate Child Labour.

ILO provided technical support to and facilitated the training for the achievement of the inauguration and training of the over 40 Agricultural Child Labour Desk Officers.

1. En el marco de la implementación del Plan Nacional de Empleo (PNE), el 30 de noviembre de 2022 el Gobierno, con el liderazgo del Ministerio de Trabajo Empleo y Seguridad Social (MTESS) del Paraguay, presenta públicamente el plan operativo del PNE, como una medida para impulsar su puesta en marcha. 
El documento fue elaborado y validado tripartita e institucionalmente, y contiene un sistema de monitoreo actualizado, incorporando datos de la Encuesta Continua de Hogares Continua como de registros administrativos, bajo la tutela técnica del Observatorio Laboral del MTESS, permitiendo que la máxima autoridad laboral reportara periódicamente sobre los avances de implementación (diciembre 2022 y agosto 2023).
El MTESS amplió la presencia de Oficinas de Empleo en varias regiones del país, incluyendo zonas con escasa presencia institucional. En agosto de 2022 se inauguró la Oficina de Empleo de Loma Plata en el Chaco paraguayo. El MTESS, junto al Servicio Nacional de Promoción Profesional y el consorcio empresarial Paracel, pusieron en marcha un programa de formación de mano de obra paraguaya para la futura planta de celulosa y su cadena de proveedores en el Departamento de Concepción, con perspectivas de una alta generación de empleo decente en un territorio con elevados índices de pobreza e informalidad laboral.
2.El 3 de mayo 2022, el Presidente de la República del Paraguay firmó el Decreto Presidencial 7029/2022 que eleva a rango de política pública nacional el Plan Nacional de Empleo (PNE), que mandata al conjunto de instituciones gubernamentales a orientar sus políticas y programas hacia la reactivación y el crecimiento económico, la estimulación de la demanda, la reconversión laboral, el potenciamiento de adecuadas habilidades y competencias, la intermediación laboral y el fortalecimiento institucional. 1. Asesoría técnica OIT para la elaboración del plan operativo y el diseño del sistema de monitoreo del PNE. Asimismo, apoyó en la organización y facilitación, en septiembre de 2022, de dos talleres (uno interinstitucional y otro tripartito) para la validación del documento. Con el Observatorio Laboral, la OIT colaboró en la documentación, evaluación, mejora de calidad y análisis de los registros administrativos del propio MTESS y del Instituto de Previsión Social (ver publicaciones periódicas “Registro de Inscripción de Establecimientos y Puestos de Trabajo” y “Principales Indicadores del Mercado Laboral”).
2.	Apoyo al MTESS en la promoción de la descentralización y regionalización de las políticas de empleo (especialmente, con la Oficina de Empleo de Loma Plata, en el marco de misión tripartita organizada en el Chaco paraguayo en agosto de 2022).
La OIT participó junto a las máximas autoridades del Estado, incluyendo el Presidente de la República, en el acto de lanzamiento del PNE, adicionalmente a los insumos técnicos y facilitación de talleres en el bienio 2020/2021.
En el primer semestre del 2023, la OIT promovió el intercambio de información que permitió consolidar el compromiso de Paraguay con el Acelerador Mundial de empleo y protección social para las transiciones justas; organizó el side event en el Foro sobre Desarrollo Sostenible en Santiago de Chile (abril 2023); gestionó la reunión entre el Ministro de Relaciones Exteriores y la Directora General Adjunta de la OIT en Nueva York (abril 2023); y facilitó reuniones de alto nivel de las autoridades nacionales en ocasión de la CIT (junio 2023). 
3.	Asesoría técnica en la revisión y el ajuste de los antecedentes de las políticas de empleo, la actualización de los diagnósticos del mercado laboral, la orientación estratégica comparativa con otras experiencias internacionales, la asesoría técnica sobre la metodología de validación tripartita y la difusión del documento del Plan Nacional de Empleo (PNE).

1. Four Roof Integrated Services Centre of Migrant Resource Centers (LTSA-MRC) in East Lampung, Cirebon, Blitar, and Tulungagung provided MRC services to 1,610 migrant workers (1,399 women). In addition to case management, counseling, information, and outreach, financial literacy training and vocational training are also provided to returnee women migrant workers. The MRC in Tulungagung district received the Indonesian Migrant Worker Award from the Ministry of Manpower for providing the best-integrated services to Indonesian migrant workers. The LTSA-MRC model is a pilot multi-stakeholder partnership between the Indonesian Government, village leaders, frontline service providers, and district-level duty bearers to develop integrated and coordinated gender-responsive services for migrant workers at all stages of their migration journey, under Law No. 18/2017 on the Protection of Indonesian Migrant Workers. The integrated LTSA-MRC model has been recognized by the UN Network on Migration as a good practice in 2022.
2. 13 village regulations were adopted in Tulungagung district and Cirebon districts to improve village-level protection mechanisms, including MRC services, for migrant workers. In Blitar districts, two (2) village decrees were adopted to establish village task forces.
3. Two Joint Commitments (MOUs) on Development in Integrating a Gender-Responsive MRC in Government One-Roof Integrated Services Offices (LTSAs) in Blitar and Tulungagung districts were adopted in 2022  The MOU was officially signed by the Head of Regent (Bupati), the President of the Indonesia Trade Union Confederation for All Workers (KSBSI) and the Secretary-General of the Indonesian Women’s Coalition (KPI), signifying ownership and partnership among diverse stakeholders and the political will to protect the rights of migrant workers. 1. With the support of the European Union, the ILO supported the establishment and operations of the integrated gender-responsive MRCs with the Government One-Roof Integrated Services Centres (LTSAs), and built the capacity of 112 MRC staff to improve their ability to provide gender-sensitive services (including case management and counseling capacity); build their knowledge on complaint mechanisms and referral services for women migrant workers who have experienced violence;  support women migrant workers’ organizing; and improve coordination and cross-sectoral collaboration among MRCs, workers’ organizations, duty bearers, and other service providers, including how to strengthen the role of the village authorities in implementing article 42 of Law No. 18/2017.
2. The ILO, with EU support, strengthened the capacity of 438 government officials and service providers at provincial, district, and village levels, through training, and cross-border exchanges, to improve gender-responsive services and information provision to migrant workers, their families, and the larger community, in keeping with Law on the Protection of Migrant Workers (No. 18/2017), and its related guidelines for implementation.
3. The ILO had previously given input to the two draft MoUs on the Development of Integrating a Gender-Responsive MRC in Government One-Roof Integrated Services Offices (LTSAs) in Blitar and Tulungagung districts, and the Gender-Responsive Guidelines on the Provision of Services and Protection of Indonesia Migrant Workers (Implementation of Law 18/17). Following its inputs, it has continued to support their adoption, launch, and implementation (with EU support).

1. En marzo del 2023, la “Mesa de Trabajo para promover el cumplimiento de los derechos de las trabajadoras y trabajadores del hogar” integrada por la Confederación Unitaria de Trabajadores del Perú (CUT), Confederación General de los Trabajadores del Perú (CGTP), Central Autónoma de Trabajadores del Perú (CATP), Confederación de Trabajadores del Perú (CTP), Federación de Trabajadoras y Trabajadores del Hogar Remunerado del Perú (Fentrahogarp), Federación Nacional Trabajadoras y Trabajadores del Hogar Perú (Fenttrahop), Ministerio de la Mujer y Poblaciones Vulnerables (MIMP), Ministerio de Trabajo y Promoción del Empleo (MTPE), Superintendencia Nacional de Fiscalización Laboral (SUNAFIL) y Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y de Administración Tributaria (SUNAT), aprobó su plan de trabajo 2023, cuyo objetivo es planificar acciones coordinadas entre el Estado, organizaciones de trabajadores y organizaciones de sociedad civil que se dedican al tema del trabajo doméstico, para potenciar el cumplimiento de los derechos de las trabajadoras del hogar y el cumplimiento de la Ley Nº 31047, Ley de las trabajadores y trabajadores del hogar. En dicho plan, se establece como una de las actividades el fortalecimiento de la vinculación entre el Sistema Nacional de Cuidados y el Trabajo del hogar desde la perspectiva del Trabajo decente.
2. En el 2022, el MTPE inició la implementación de la Ley Nº 31047 a través de la aplicación de herramientas de gestión y recursos informativos para asegurar que las trabajadoras del hogar cuenten con información estandarizada y resumida. Estas herramientas son difundidas en la web del Ministerio dirigido a trabajadoras del hogar y empleadores: Compendio normativo “Normas sobre los derechos de las personas trabajadoras del hogar”, “Guía práctica de los derechos de las personas trabajadoras del hogar” y video tutorial para la inscripción en el aplicativo web “Registro de Trabajo del Hogar”. 1. Con el apoyo del gobierno de Canadá, en febrero 2023, la OIT proporcionó asistencia técnica para realizar el taller denominado “Evaluación 2022 y Planificación de actividades 2023”, que tuvo por finalidad diseñar y definir la elaboración del plan de trabajo 2023. El resultado de dicho taller fue una propuesta de planificación que el MTPE compartió con los integrantes de la Mesa y que con sus aportes fue aprobado en la sesión de marzo del mismo año. Asimismo, la OIT presentó en la sesión Nº 15 de la “Mesa de Trabajo para promover el cumplimiento de los derechos de las trabajadoras y trabajadores del hogar”, la Hoja de Ruta para avanzar hacia el trabajo decente para las trabajadoras domésticas remuneradas en América Latina (“Hacer del trabajo doméstico un trabajo decente: Invertir en cuidado. Una agenda común”). Esta es una propuesta iberoamericana que fue elaborada por la OIT y validada en el I Simposio Iberoamericano de Cuidados y Trabajo Doméstico realizado en Cartagena. Esta hoja de ruta también se incluyó dentro del plan de trabajo.
2. Con el apoyo del gobierno de Canadá, en segundo semestre 2022, la OIT elaboró en coordinación con el Ministerio de Trabajo y Promoción del Empleo el compendio normativo “Normas sobre los derechos de las personas trabajadoras del hogar”, “Guía práctica de los derechos de las personas trabajadoras del hogar” y video tutorial para la inscripción en el aplicativo web “Registro de Trabajo del Hogar”.

1. In 2022, the district government in Cirebon adopted the Joint Commitment (MOU) on the Establishment of Tripartite Plus Forum for Coordination and Social Dialogue on Labour Migration, which will enable migrant workers to join tripartite constituents in village-level policy discussions and dialogues. The Tripartite Plus Forum for Coordination and Social Dialogue on Labour Migration was jointly established with Indonesia’s Migrant Workers Union and Women Crisis Centre of Mawar Balqis.
2. Statistics Indonesia (BPS) adopted guidelines for the government to align the labour migration data of the SDMI with the ILO’s international labour migration statistics (ILMS) database. The guidelines were developed in cooperation with the Ministry of Manpower, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, National Agency for the Protection of Indonesian Migrant Workers and Ministry of Law and Human Rights, and have been used in capacity-building trainings for line ministries. Improved collection, use and sharing of labour migration statistics supports better evidence-based policy-making and service provision for migrant workers.
3. The Ministry of Manpower had drafted a Monitoring Tool for the Implementation of Ministry of Manpower Decree No 294/2020 on the Implementation of Placement in the New Normal Period, in 2022. The Monitoring Tool supports the implementation of the SOPs for private recruitment agencies and private technical and vocational education and training (TVET) institutions for overseas workers. The SOPs themselves require TVETs and placement agencies who are sending Indonesian workers abroad, to adopt occupational safety and health (OSH) principles and follow a survivor-centred approach in their complaint and referral mechanism for cases related to violence, harassment, human and labour rights violations, and COVID-19 infections. In 2023, the Tool will be used in labour inspection as the Labour Inspection Checklist for Placement and Protection of Indonesia Migrant Workers. 1. To ensure that migrant workers, especially women migrant workers, can participate on an equal footing in decision-making processes, ILO, with EU support, and in close cooperation with the Indonesian Government, has initiated village-level Tripartite Plus Forums for Coordination and Social Dialogue on Labour Migration which provide an inclusive platform for migrant workers to voice their demands and aspirations to policymakers and key stakeholders, and to have a say on the effectiveness of government coordination in implementing Law No. 18/2017 and gender-responsive coordinated services for migrant workers.
2. ILO, with the support of the EU, has supported  Statistics Indonesia (BPS) to strengthen the One Data Indonesia on International Migration (SDMI) platform initiated by BPS. This support has taken the form of guidelines on aligning the SDMI data collection with the definitions and definitions on International Labour Migration Statistic (ILMS) under the ILO’s central database, ILOSTAT. The guidelines have been adopted and were used to train 30 government officials to build their capacity for ILMS data submission and its alignment with the SDMI. 
3. ILO continued to strengthen the implementation of Ministry of Manpower Decree No. 294/2020 on the Implementation of Placement of Indonesian Migrant Workers during the Period of Adaptation to the New Habits, by providing technical inputs (as well as facilitating the inclusion of inputs from other stakeholders) into the drafting process of the Monitoring Tool for the Implementation of Ministry of Manpower Decree No 294/2020 on the Implementation of Placement in the New Normal Period. ILO supported a focus group discussion to test the draft tools with representatives from private recruitment agencies and technical, vocational education and training (TVET) institutions. Recommendations sought to strengthen the means of providing gender-responsive services and to ensure their usage by the Labour Inspectorate.

1. The Ministry of Expatriates' Welfare and Overseas Employment (MOEWOE) has developed ‘Action Plan (2021-2025) of the 8th Five Year Plan on Overseas Employment and Well-being of Migrant Workers’ in December 2022 and started implementing the action plan since December 2022. The plan commits the government to establishing fair recruitment, skill development and protection of migrant workers in line with International Labour Standards, and to working through tripartite social dialogue.
2. The Government of Bangladesh (MOEWOE) has drafted and validated the Reintegration Policy for migrant workers from February 2022 to April 2023 which is now under the process of cabinet approval. The policy covers overarching directives for reintegration (including returnee database and one-stop centres), social reintegration of returnee migrants (including universal social protection), economic reintegration of returnee migrants (including active labour market policies), physical and psychosocial well-being of returnees and their family members and effective coordination and management of the reintegration process.
3. The Government of Bangladesh (MOEWOE) has gazetted Wage Earners’ Welfare Board rule in April 2023 strengthening reintegration services and access to justice for returning migrant workers. 
4. The MOEWOE adopted the unified pre-departure orientation module for outgoing migrant workers in November 2022.
5. For the first time, the GOB has introduced labour migration module related to the cost of migration in the Labour Force Survey 2022 addressing SDG target 10.7.1. 1.1 With the support of the Government of Switzerland, ILO acted as a member secretary of the technical working committee to develop the action plan during March- December 2022. 
1.2 ILO conducted 13 meetings of the technical working committee including MOEWOE, Bureau of Manpower, Employment and Training (BMET), Wage Earners’ Welfare Board (WEWB), Probashi Kallyan Bank (PKB) and Bangladesh Overseas Employment and Services Limited (BOESL) during March- December 2022
1.3 ILO conducted one validation workshop of the draft action plan on 30 August 2022 with more than 80 officials of tripartite plus constituents. 
1.4 ILO has supported the printing and dissemination of 600 copies of the action plan to relevant stakeholders and also supported the orientation of 25 officials of MOE, BMET, WEWB, PKB, and BOESL to implement and reporting of the action plan. 
2.1 ILO acted as a member secretary for the technical working committee to support the development of the draft policy from February 2022 to April 2023. 
2.2 ILO in collaboration with IOM and UN Women conducted 16 meetings of the technical committee to develop the draft of the reintegration policy. 
2.3 ILO supported two national consultations on 27 February and 22 March 2022 and one validation workshop on 31 March 2022 of the draft reintegration policy.
3.1 ILO acted as the member secretary for WEWB rule development technical committee as member secretary. Eleven consultation meetings with tripartite plus constituents to develop the WEWB rule and drafting of the rule took place between January 2022 to December 2022. 
4.1 ILO has supported developing the unified pre-departure orientation module for outgoing migrant workers through eight bilateral meetings and two technical workshops. 
 5.1 ILO supported BBS in the development of labour migration module related to cost of migration for the labour force survey through a series of consultation meetings with relevant stakeholders.

The ILO’s biennial Programme Implementation Report is an instrument of accountability. It describes the performance of the Organization against the commitments made in the Programme and Budget documents for the corresponding biennial period.

The ILO’s Decent Work Results Dashboard –complementing the ILO’s Programme Implementation Report – presents information on the results achieved and on the most significant outputs delivered by the ILO during the relevant biennium.
The ILO’s Results Framework is always part of the Programme and Budget (P&B) document for the relevant biennium. Please refer to the Annex “Results Framework” of the relevant P&B Document
The ILO’s Decent Work Results Dashboard
The ILO’s Results Framework for the biennium
1.1.1. Number of EBMOs with improved governance systems, strategies to widen representation and/or enhanced service provision
1.2.1. Number of national workers’ organizations with innovative strategies to attract new groups of workers and/or to improve their services
7.5.2. Number of Member States with new or improved services to protect the labour rights of migrant workers
1.2.2. Number of workers’ organizations that produce proposals to be considered in social dialogue mechanisms for policymaking
2.3.1. Percentage of reports on the application of ratified Conventions due by 1 September received in a timely manner that include replies to comments of the supervisory bodies

1.4.1. Number of Member States with newly developed or strengthened institutions, mechanisms or regulatory frameworks for social dialogue, labour relations or dispute prevention/resolution that address current and emerging challenges in the world of work

7.5.1. Number of Member States with labour migration frameworks or institutional mechanisms to protect the labour rights of migrant workers and promote coherence with employment, skills, social protection, and other relevant policies
1.1.2. Number of EBMOs that produce analyses on the changing business environment and conduct advocacy activities to influence policymaking.
4.2.1. Number of Member States with effective interventions to support productivity, entrepreneurship, innovation and enterprise sustainability
3.1.1. Number of Member States with new generation of national employment policies addressing country-specific future of work challenges

8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services
